task.title: Reusable Steps
task.shortdesc: You can conref these steps. Don't change anything in this file without checking where it is used.

cmd.draft-comment: The following two step are used in Configuring a Pipeline and the tutorial pipeline config topic.

step.cmd: From the Home page or Getting Started page, click Create New Pipeline.

info.note: To get to the Home page, click the Home icon.

step.cmd: In the New Pipeline window, enter a pipeline name and optional description, and click Save.
step.stepresult: The pipeline canvas displays the pipeline name and an error icon. The error icon indicates that you need to configure error handling for the pipeline. The Properties panel displays the pipeline properties.

cmd.draft-comment: The steps below are for data preview. They are used in "Previewing a Single Stage" and "Previewing Multiple Stages."

step.cmd: Above the pipeline canvas, click the Preview icon: .
step.info: If the Preview icon is disabled, check the Issues list for unconnected stages and required properties that are not defined.

step.cmd: In the Preview Configuration dialog box, configure the following properties, then click Run Preview.

row.entry:
Source data for the preview:
Configured Source - Provides data from the origin system.
Snapshot Data - Uses available snapshot data.

Number of records to use in the preview. Honors values up to the preview batch size.
Default is 10. The default is 10.
Milliseconds to wait for preview data. Use to limit the time data preview waits for data to arrive at the origin. Relevant for transient origins only.

Determines whether the preview writes data to pipeline destinations.
By default, does not write data to destinations.
Displays record metadata in List view. Headers do not display in Table view.
Displays the data type for fields in List view. Field types do not display in Table view.
When using a snapshot for source data, select the snapshot to use.

Stores the current preview configuration for use every time you request a preview for this pipeline.
After you run data preview, you can change this option in the Preview panel by selecting the Preview Configuration icon () and clearing the option. The change takes effect the next time you run data preview.

step.stepresult:
The Preview panel highlights the origin stage and displays preview data in table view. Since this is the origin of the pipeline, no input data displays.
To view preview data in list view, click the List View icon: .

step.cmd: To delete a record that you do not want to use, click the Delete icon.
To refresh the preview, click the Refresh Preview icon: .
step.info: Based on the origin, refreshing the preview either provides a new set of data or reverts any changes to the existing data.

step.cmd: To exit data preview and return to pipeline configuration, click Close Preview.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used in "Previewing a Single Stage" and "Reviewing Snapshot Data"

step.cmd: To view data for the next stage, click the Next Stage icon. Or, to view data for a different stage, select the stage in the pipeline canvas.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStepErrorHandling - Use this step for origins that are not cluster origins. Standalone only

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-ClusterOrigin - Use for origins that ARE cluster origins - points out stop pipeline is not valid.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-StageLib-EHandling - Use this step for non-cluster origins with stage libraries.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVROFILE - The following step is used by Directory, other file-based origins that read avro from files.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, optionally configure the following property:

row.entry:
Avro schema definition to use when processing data. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data. Defining a schema can improve performance.
When not used, the origin uses the schema defined in the file.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVROHadoopFS - The following step is used by HadoopFS origin only.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, optionally configure the following property:

row.entry:
Avro schema definition to use when processing data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVRO-Mess - The following step is used by JMS, Kafka, Kinesis - origins that read Avro data from messages.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Indicates that the message includes an Avro schema.

Avro schema definition to use when processing data. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data. Defining a schema can improve performance.
When not used, the origin uses the schema defined in the file.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.

cmd.draft-comment: O-Binary . Used by Kafka and Kinesis Consumer, Redis Consumer

step.cmd: For binary data, click the Binary tab and configure the following property:

row.entry: Maximum number of bytes in the message. Larger messages cannot be processed or written to error.

cmd.draft-comment: O-Datagram - just Kafka Consumer right now.

step.cmd: For datagram data, on the Datagram tab, configure the following properties:

cmd.draft-comment: DELIMITED data - Directory, Hadoop FS, JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer, Kinesis Consumer, Redis Consumer - all file & message origins

step.cmd: For delimited data, on the Delimited tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Delimiter format type. Use one of the following options:
Indicates whether a file contains a header line, and whether to use the header line.
Maximum length of a record in characters. Longer records are not read.

Delimiter character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
You can enter a Unicode control character using the format \uNNNN, where â€‹N is a hexadecimal digit from the numbers 0-9 or the letters A-F. For example, enter \u0000 to use the null character as the delimiter or \u2028 to use a line separator as the delimiter.
Default is the pipe character ( | ).
Escape character for a custom file type.
Quote character for a custom file type.

Root field type to use:
List-Map - Generates an indexed list of data. Enables you to use standard functions to process data. Use for new pipelines.
List - Generates a record with an indexed list with a map for header and value. Requires the use of delimited data functions to process data. Use only to maintain pipelines created before 1.1.0.
Lines to skip before reading data.
Replaces the specified string constant with null values.
String constant to replace with null values.

cmd.draft-comment: JSON-2props - Kafka Consumer, JMS Consumer, Hadoop FS, Kinesis all use them. HTTP Client, and probably others use the 2nd row.

step.cmd: For JSON data, on the JSON tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Type of JSON content. Use one of the following options:
Array of Objects
Multiple Objects

Maximum number of characters in a JSON object.
Longer objects are diverted to the pipeline for error handling.

cmd.draft-comment: LOG data - Used in JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer, Hadoop FS, probably Directory. Use the following for origins that use the Log data format. UL in first row is also being conrefed in Log Parser.
Also - For any changes to the bullets below this first table, update Log Parser as well. Everything except the Log4j table/bullet point is copied from here.

step.cmd: For log data, on the Log tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Format of the log files. Use one of the following options:
Common Log Format
Combined Log Format
Apache Error Log Format
Apache Access Log Custom Format
Regular Expression
Grok Pattern
Log4j
Maximum length of a log line. The origin truncates longer lines.

Determines how to treat the original log line. Select to include the original log line as a field in the resulting record.
By default, the original line is discarded.

ul.li: When you select Apache Access Log Custom Format, use Apache log format strings to define the Custom Log Format.
When you select Regular Expression, enter the regular expression that describes the log format, and then map the fields that you want to include to each regular expression group.

When you select Grok Pattern, you can use the Grok Pattern Definition field to define custom grok patterns. You can define a pattern on each line.
In the Grok Pattern field, enter the pattern to use to parse the log. You can use a predefined grok patterns or create a custom grok pattern using patterns defined in Grok Pattern Definition.
For more information about defining grok patterns and supported grok patterns, see .

When you select Log4j, define the following properties:
Log4j Property Description
On Parse Error Determines how to handle information that cannot be parsed:
Skip and Log Error - Skips reading the line and logs a stage error.
Skip, No Error - Skips reading the line and does not log an error.
Include as Stack Trace - Includes information that cannot be parsed as a stack trace to the previously-read log line. The information is added to the message field for the last valid log line.
Use Custom Log Format Allows you to define a custom log format.
Custom Format Use log4j variables to define a custom log format.

cmd.draft-comment:
O-PROTO-Mess. Step used by message-reading stages except for Kafka. Kafka conrefs the first two rows of table.
NOTE: When making changes, make sure to update the file version and destination versions, as necessary.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Protobuf tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For information about generating the descriptor file, see . For more information about environment variables, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when reading data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.
Indicates if a message might include more than one protobuf message.

cmd.draft-comment:
O-Proto-File. Step used by file-based proto.
NOTE: When making changes, make sure to update the message version and destination versions, as necessary.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Protobuf tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For more information about environment variables, see . For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when reading data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.
Indicates if a file might include more than one protobuf message.

cmd.draft-comment: TEXT data - Directory, Kafka Consumer, Hadoop FS, Kinesis Consumer, JMS Consumer

step.cmd: For text data, on the Text tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Maximum number of characters allowed for a line. Longer lines are truncated.
Adds a boolean field to the record to indicate if it was truncated. The field name is Truncated.
Uses custom delimiters to define records instead of line breaks.
One more more characters to use to define records.
Includes delimiter characters in the record.

cmd.draft-comment: O-WholeFile - Directory

step.cmd: For whole files on the Whole File tab, configure the following property:

row.entry: Maximum buffer size to use when transferring data.

cmd.draft-comment: O-WholeFile-Checksum - S3

step.cmd: For whole files, on the Whole File tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Maximum buffer size to use when transferring data.
Verifies the checksum during the read.

cmd.draft-comment: XML data - step used by message and file based origins: JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer, Hadoop FS, Kinesis Consumer, Directory, S3, HTTP Client, maybe more.

step.cmd: For XML data, on the XML tab, configure the following properties:

entry.p: XML element that acts as a delimiter. Omit a delimiter to treat the entire XML document as one record.
Use the XML element name without surrounding angle brackets ( < > ) . For example, msg instead of <msg>.
The maximum number of characters in a record. Longer records are diverted to the pipeline for error handling.

cmd.draft-comment: ORIGIN-MIXED REUSE - The following handful of steps are for origin/origin, origin/processor or possibly origin/destination reuse. In alphabetical order.
HTTPClient-Credentials - The following steps are used in HTTP Client origin and processor Configuring topics:

step.cmd: When using authentication, on the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: User name for basic, digest, or universal authentication.
Password for basic, digest, or universal authentication.

cmd.draft-comment: HTTPClient-Proxy - - The following steps are used in HTTP Client origin and processor Configuring topics:

step.cmd: To use an HTTP proxy, on the Proxy tab, configure the following properties:

cmd.draft-comment: HTTPClient-SSLTLS - same as above

step.cmd: Optionally, on the SSL/TLS tab, configure truststore and keystore details:

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in JDBC Consumer, JDBC Producer, JDBC Lookup, and JDBC Tee config topics. Oracle CDC Client is using some info from the Credentials table, and the whole Legacy Drivers step.

step.cmd: To enter JDBC credentials separately from the JDBC connection string, on the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: User name for the JDBC connection.

step.cmd: When using JDBC versions older than 4.0, on the Legacy Drivers tab, optionally configure the following properties:

row.entry: Class name for the JDBC driver. Required for JDBC versions older than version 4.0.
Optional query to test the health of a connection. Recommended only when the JDBC version is older than 4.0.

cmd.draft-comment: Rows in this table are used by Kafka Consumer and SDC RPC to Kafka origins, also UDP to Kafka.

row.entry:
Connection string for the Kafka broker. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
To ensure a connection, enter a comma-separated list of additional broker URI.

entry.p: Additional Kafka configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the Kafka property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by Kafka.
For information about enabling secure connections to Kafka, see .

cmd.draft-comment: RabbitMQ - Entire step used by Consumer, rows used by Producer

step.cmd: On the RabbitMQ tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
RabbitMQ URI.
Typically uses the following format: amqp:<host>:<port>/<virtualhost>.
RabbitMQ consumer tag. Leave empty to use an automatically generated consumer tag.

Generates a single record for each RabbitMQ message.
When not selected, the origin generates a record for each object in the message.

Additional RabbitMQ client configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the RabbitMQ client property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by RabbitMQ.
Enables the use of RabbitMQ credentials.

Type of data to be read. Use one of the following data formats:
Avro
Binary
Delimited
JSON
Log
Protobuf
SDC Record
Text
XML

step.cmd: On the Credentials tab, enter the RabbitMQ credentials to use if you enabled credentials.
On the Queue tab, configure the following queue properties:
step.info:
These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.
Queue Property Description
Name Name of the queue to use or create.
Durable Creates a durable queue when selected.
The stage creates a durable queue by default.
Exclusive Creates an exclusive queue when selected. When exclusive, the queue allows only the to use it.
The stage creates an exclusive queue by default.
Auto-Delete Automatically deletes a queue after all consumers unsubscribe.
When used with an exclusive queue, the queue is automatically deleted when you stop the pipeline.
Declaration Properties Additional queue declaration properties to use.

step.cmd: On the Exchange tab, optionally configure the following binding properties for the bindings that you want to use. When no bindings are configured, the default exchange is used.
step.info:
These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.
Exchange Property Description
Name Binding name.
Type Binding type.
Durable Creates a durable exchange.
Auto-Delete Automatically deletes an exchange when all queues are finished using it.
Routing Key Routing key.
Leave empty to default to the queue name.
Declaration Properties Additional exchange properties to use.
Binding Properties Additional binding properties to use.

step.cmd: Optionally configure advanced options on the Advanced tab.
step.info: These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.

Generally, you should use the defaults for these properties:
Advanced Property Description
Automatic Recovery Enabled Determines whether to attempt to reestablish a connection.
Network Recovery Interval Milliseconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a network connection.
Default is 5000.
Connection Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the connection to establish. Use 0 to opt out of a connection timeout.
Default is 0.
Handshake Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the handshake to complete.
Shutdown Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the shutdown to complete.
Heartbeat Timeout (secs) Seconds to wait for a heartbeat to verify that RabbitMQ is up and the connection still available.
Use 0 to avoid requesting heartbeats. Default is 0.
Maximum Frame Size (bytes) Maximum frame size in bytes. Use for performance tuning.
Setting a larger value can improve throughput. Setting a smaller value can improve latency.
Use 0 for no limit. Default is 0.
Maximum Channel Number Maximum number of channels allowed.

cmd.draft-comment: The following is used for SDC RPC origins

row.entry: Port number to listen to for data. Must match one of the port numbers associated with the SDC RPC destination that provides the data.
User-defined ID. Must match the RPC ID defined in the SDC RPC destination.

Enables the secure transfer of data using TLS.
To use encryption, both the origin and SDC RPC destination must be enabled for TLS.

Keystore file for SSL.
Must be stored in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES. For more information about environment variables, see .

cmd.draft-comment: O-UDPprops - whole step used by UDP Source. Rows in this table by UDP to Kafka. Data Format is also used by Configuring the Kafka Consumer > Datagram step.

step.cmd: On the UDP tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Port to listen to for data. To list additional ports, click the Add icon.To listen to a port below 1024, must be run by a user with root privileges. Otherwise, the operating system does not allow to bind to the port.

Data format passed by UDP:
collectd
NetFlow
syslog

Maximum number of messages include in a batch and pass through the pipeline at one time. Honors values up to the maximum batch size.
Default is 1000. The default is 1000.
Milliseconds to wait before sending a partial or empty batch.

cmd.draft-comment: O-UDP-collectd - used by UDP Source and entries and ph used in Kafka Consumer.

step.cmd: On the collectd tab, define the following collectd properties:

entry.ph: Path to a user-provided types.db file. Overrides the default types.db file.
Converts the collectd high resolution time format interval and timestamp to UNIX time, in milliseconds.
Excludes the interval field from output record.
Path to an optional authentication file. Use an authentication file to accept signed and encrypted data.

cmd.draft-comment: Use this step for processors that have error handling - should be almost all.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Fields that must include data to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: Use the following step for processors without record handling - Field Remover, Record Deduplicator.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Fields that must include data to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-NoStageLib - Use for destinations without stage libs, e.g. Local FS.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Fields that must include data to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-StageLib-ReqField-EHandling - Use this step for destinations with stage library, req fields, and error handling. â€“ Some rows are used by Hive Metastore.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.
Fields that must include data to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-Event - Used in Flume. Flume doesn't have other compression types, so it's not getting that note.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Indicates that the Avro schema is embedded in the avroSchema record header attribute.
Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Schema definition to use when writing data.
Includes the schema in each event. Omitting the schema definition can improve performance, but requires the appropriate schema management to avoid losing track of the schema associated with the data.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression for the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-File - used in Amazon S3 and other file-based destinations that write avro.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Indicates that the Avro schema is embedded in the avroSchema record header attribute. The destination includes the schema definition in each generated file.
Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Schema definition to use when writing data. The destination includes the schema definition in each generated file.

The Avro-supported compression type to use.
When you enable Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-Mess - Used in KProducer and KinFirehose.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Avro tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Indicates that the Avro schema is embedded in the avroSchema record header attribute.
Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Schema definition to use when writing data.

Includes the schema in each message. Omitting the schema definition can improve performance, but requires the appropriate schema management to avoid losing track of the schema associated with the data.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-Binary - Used by Kafka Consumer and Amazon S3 dest.

step.cmd: For binary data, on the Binary tab, configure the following property:

row.entry: Field that contains the binary data.

cmd.draft-comment: DelimProps: Use for the appropriate delimited destinations - currently Amazon S3, Flume, Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, and Kinesis Firehose:

step.cmd: For delimited data, on the Delimited tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Indicates whether to create a header line.

Replaces new line characters with the configured string.
Recommended when writing data as a single line of text.

String to replace each new line character. For example, enter a space to replace each new line character with a space.
Leave empty to remove the new line characters.

Delimiter character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
You can enter a Unicode control character using the format \uNNNN, where â€‹N is a hexadecimal digit from the numbers 0-9 or the letters A-F. For example, enter \u0000 to use the null character as the delimiter or \u2028 to use a line separator as the delimiter.
Default is the pipe character ( | ).

Escape character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
Default is the backslash character ( \ ).

Quote character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
Default is the quotation mark character ( " ).

cmd.draft-comment: JSONProps - Used for Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, Amazon S3, Kinesis Producer, and Kinesis Firehose.

step.cmd: For JSON data, on the JSON tab, configure the following property:

row.entry:
Determines how JSON data is written:
JSON Array of Objects - Each file includes a single array. In the array, each element is a JSON representation of each record.
Multiple JSON Objects - Each file includes multiple JSON objects. Each object is a JSON representation of a record.

cmd.draft-comment: TextProps - Using for Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, and Amazon S3.

step.cmd: For text data, on the Text tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Field that contains the text data to be written. All data must be incorporated into the specified field.

Creates an empty line when a record does not include the text field specified above.
When not selected, records without the specified text field are discarded.

cmd.draft-comment:
D-PROTO-props - used by all protobuf destinations
NOTE: when making changes, make sure to make any related ones to BOTH origin tables.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Protobuf tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For more information about environment variables, see . For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when reading data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.

info.draft-comment: D-WHOLEFile-props - Whole table used by Hadoop FS, Local FS, and MapR FS. Rows used by S3.

step.cmd: For whole files, on the Whole File tab, configure the following properties:

entry.p: Expression to use for the file name.
Default is ${record:value('/fileInfo/filename')}, which uses the original source file name as the target file name.

row.entry:
Action to take when a file of the same name already exists in the target directory. Use one of the following options:
Send to Error - Handles the record based on stage error record handling.
Overwrite - Overwrites the existing file.

cmd.draft-comment: FS-OutputFiles - Hadoop FS, Local FS and MapR FS conref rows/partial rows in the table

step.cmd: On the Output Files tab, configure the following options:

row.entry:
Maximum time that an output file can remain idle. After no records are written to a file for this amount of time, the destination closes the file. Enter a time in seconds or use the MINUTES or HOURS constant in an expression to define the time increment.
Use -1 to set no limit. Default is 1 hour, defined as follows: ${1 * HOURS}.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Output file type:
Text files
Sequence files
Whole files - Select when using the whole file data format.

Format of data to be written. Use one of the following options:
Avro
Binary
Delimited
JSON
Protobuf
Text
Whole File

Prefix to use for output files. Use when writing to a directory that receives files from other sources.
Uses the prefix sdc-${sdc:id()} by default. The prefix evaluates to sdc-<Data Collector ID>.
The Data Collector ID is stored in the following file: $SDC_DATA/sdc.id. For more information about environment variables, see .
Indicates that the target directory is defined in record headers. Use only when the targetDirectory header attribute is defined for all records.

Template for creating output directories. You can use constants, field values, and datetime variables.
Output directories are created based on the smallest datetime variable in the template.
Time zone for the destination system. Used to resolve datetimes in the directory template and evaluate where records are written.

Time basis to use for creating output directories and writing records to the directories. Use one of the following expressions:
${time:now()} - Uses the processing time as the time basis.
${record:value(<date field path>)} - Uses the time associated with the record as the time basis.

Maximum number of records to be written to an output file. Additional records are written to a new file.
Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Maximum size of an output file. Additional records are written to a new file.
Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Compression type for output files:
None
gzip
bzip2
Snappy
LZ4
Other
Full class name of the other compression codec that you want to use.

Compression type for sequence files when using a compression codec:
Block Compression
Record Compression

Checks the record header for the roll header attribute and closes the current file when the roll attribute exists.
Can be used with Max Records in a File and Max File Size to close files.

Name of the roll header attribute.
Default is roll.

When you start the pipeline, the destination tries writing to the configured directory template to validate permissions. The pipeline does not start if validation fails.Do not use this option when the directory template uses expressions to represent the entire directory.

cmd.draft-comment: Elasticsearch properties - used by Elasticsearch destination and Configuring a Pipeline > Error handling.

step.cmd: On the Elasticsearch tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
URI of one or more nodes in the cluster. Use the following format: <host>:<port>
To ensure a connection, enter a comma-separated list of URIs.

Use when the cluster uses a custom HTTP URI. Use the following format: <host>:<port>
Unless configured, the destination uses the default HTTP URI to verify that the cluster version is compatible with the destination libraries.
Enables access to a Shield-protected cluster.

Enables access to an Elastic Cloud cluster.
Selecting this property is the equivalent to setting the action.bulk.compress Elasticsearch property to false, and the request.headers.X-Found-Cluster to the cluster name.
Elastic Cloud requires Shield. When enabling Elastic Cloud, enable Shield and configure the additional Shield properties.

Detects additional nodes in the cluster based on the configured Cluster URI. Selecting this property is the equivalent to setting the client.transport.sniff Elasticsearch property to true.
Use only when the shares the same network as the Elasticsearch cluster. Do not use for Elastic Cloud or Docker clusters.
Additional Elasticsearch properties that you want to use. Enter the exact property name and value expected by Elasticsearch.

entry.p:
Time basis to use for writing to time-based indexes. Use one of the following expressions:
${time:now()} - Uses the processing time as the time basis. The processing time is the time associated with the running the pipeline.
An expression that calls a field and resolves to a datetime value, such as ${record:value(<date field path>)}. Uses the datetime result as the time basis.
When the Index definition does not include datetime variables, you can ignore this property.

row.entry: Time zone for the destination system. Used to resolve datetimes in time-based indexes.

Index information for the generated documents. You can use a constant, datetime variables, a field that includes the index information, or any valid combination.
When using datetime variables, make sure to configure the time basis appropriately. For details about datetime variables, see .
Mapping information for the generated documents. You can use a constant or a field that includes the mapping information.

ID for the record. Use to specify the ID for the generated documents. When you do not specify an ID, Elasticsearch creates an ID for each document.
By default, the destination allows Elasticsearch to create the ID.

entry.p: Character encoding of the data to be processed.

row.entry: Enables upserts to the cluster. When enabled, configure the Document ID property.

step.cmd: When writing to a Shield-protected cluster, on the Shield tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Shield username and password.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.user Elasticsearch property.

Enables SSL between the and the Elasticsearch cluster.
Selecting this property is the equivalent to setting the shield.transport.ssl Elasticsearch property to true.

Location of the keystore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.keystore.path Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.

Password for the keystore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.keystore.password Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.

Location of the truststore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.truststore.path Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.

Password for the truststore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.truststore.password Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.

cmd.draft-comment: FS-LateRecords - for Hadoop FS and Local FS

step.cmd: On the Late Records tab, configure the following properties:

info.note: These properties are relevant for a time basis based on the time of a record. If you use processing time as the time basis, set the late record time limit to one second.

row.entry:
Time limit for output directories to accept data.
You can enter a time in seconds, or use the expression to enter a time in hours. You can also use MINUTES in the default expression to define the time in minutes.

Determines how to handle late records:
Send to error - Sends the record to the stage for error handling.
Send to late records file - Sends the record to a late records file.

Template for creating late record directories. You can use constants, field values, and datetime variables.
Output directories are created based on the smallest datetime variable in the template.

cmd.draft-comment: KafkaConfig - used for the Kafka Producer - Kafka tab properties. Rows in the table are used for Configuring a Pipeline, error handling > Write to Kafka, and DPM chapter > Aggregated Statistics > Configuring a Pipeline to Aggregate Statistics. -- Message per Batch also used by RabbitMQ Producer. Some rows also used by MapR Streams Producer.

step.cmd: On the Kafka tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Connection string for the Kafka broker. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
To ensure a connection, enter a comma-separated list of additional broker URI.
Evaluates an expression at runtime to determine the topic to use for each record.

Topic to use.
Not available when using runtime topic resolution.
Expression used to determine where each record is written when using runtime topic resolution. Use an expression that evaluates to a topic name.

List of valid topic names to write to when using runtime topic resolution. Use to avoid writing to invalid topics. Records that resolve to invalid topic names are passed to the stage for error handling.
Use an asterisk (*) to allow writing to any topic name. By default, all topic names are valid.

Strategy to use to write to partitions:
Round Robin - Takes turns writing to different partitions.
Random - Writes to partitions randomly.
Expression - Uses an expression to write data to different partitions.
Default - Uses the default partition strategy that Kafka provides.

Expression to use when using the expression partition strategy.
Define the expression to evaluate to the partition where you want each record written. Partition numbers start with 0.
For each batch, writes the records to each partition as a single message.

Additional Kafka properties to use. Click the Add icon and define the Kafka property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by Kafka. Do not use the broker.list property.
For information about enabling secure connections to Kafka, see .

Data format for messages:
Avro
Binary
Delimited
JSON
Protobuf
SDC Record
Text

cmd.draft-comment: MapRStreams-props - used by MapR Streams Producer and Info tag used by Configuring a Pipeline > Write to MapR Streams.

step.cmd: On the MapR Streams Producer tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Additional configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by MapR.
You can use MapR Streams properties and set of Kafka properties supported by MapR Streams.

cmd.draft-comment: RPCdest - Used for Config RPC Dest and pipeline error handling > Write to pipeline.

step.cmd: On the RPC tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Connection information for the destination pipeline to continue processing data. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
Use a single RPC connection for each destination pipeline. Add additional connections as needed.
Use the port number when you configure the SDC RPC origin that receives the data.
User-defined ID to allow the destination to pass data to an SDC RPC origin. Use this ID in all SDC RPC origins to process data from the destination.

Enables the secure transfer of data using TLS.
To use encryption, both the SDC RPC origin and SDC RPC destination must be enabled for TLS.

Truststore file for TLS. Required if the keystore file is a self-signed certificate.
Must be stored in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES. For more information about environment variables, see .
Verifies the host in the SDC RPC origin keystore file.

cmd.draft-comment: RPCdestAdv - Used in RPC destination & pipeline error config - write to pipeline.

step.cmd: On the Advanced tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Number of times the destination tries to write a batch to the SDC RPC origin.
When the destination cannot write the batch within the configured number of retries, it fails the batch.
Default is 3.

Milliseconds to establish a connection to the SDC RPC origin.
The destination retries the connection based on the Retries Per Batch property.
Default is 5000 milliseconds.

Milliseconds to wait for the SDC RPC origin to read data from a batch.
The destination retries the write based on the Retries Per Batch property.
Default is 2000 milliseconds.
Enables the destination to use compression to pass data to the SDC RPC origin. Enabled by default.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in "Step 1. Install the StreamSets Custom Service Descriptor" in the Installation chapter and the Upgrade chapter.

step.cmd: Use the following URL to download the CSD from the StreamSets website: .
Copy the CSD file to the Local Descriptor Repository Path. By default, the path is /opt/cloudera/csd.
step.info: To verify the path to use, in Cloudera Manager, click Administration Settings . In the navigation panel, select the Custom Service Descriptors category. Place the CSD file in the path configured for Local Descriptor Repository Path.

step.cmd: Set the file ownership to cloudera-scm:cloudera-scm with permission 644.
Use one of the following commands to restart Cloudera Manager Server:
step.info: For Ubuntu and CentOS 6: service cloudera-scm-server restartFor CentOS 7: systemctl restart cloudera-scm-server

step.cmd: In Cloudera Manager, to restart the Cloudera Management Service, click Home Status . To the right of Cloudera Management Service, click the Menu icon and select Restart.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in "Step 2. Manually Install the Parcel and Checksum Files (Optional)" used in the Installation and Upgrade chapters.

step.cmd: Download the StreamSets parcel and related checksum file for the Cloudera Manager Server operating system from the following location:
Copy the StreamSets parcel and checksum files to the Cloudera Manager Local Parcel Repository Path.
step.info: To verify the path to use, click Administration Settings . In the navigation panel, select the Parcels category. Place the StreamSets parcel file in the path configured for Local Parcel Repository Path.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used for the Enabling SSL topics for the MongoDB origin and destination

step.cmd: In the Advanced tab for the stage, select the SSL Enabled property.
Define the following options in the SDC_JAVA_OPTS environment variable in the Data Collector environment configuration file, sdc-env.sh or sdcd-env.sh:

info.p: For example, define the options as follows:export SDC_JAVA_OPTS="-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=<path to truststore file> -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=<password> -Dhttps.protocols=TLSv1.2,TLSv1.1 -Xmx1024m -Xms1024m -XX:PermSize=256M -XX:MaxPermSize=512M -server ${SDC_JAVA_OPTS}"

step.cmd: Restart to enable the changes.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used for the MongoDB origin and destination configuring topics.

step.cmd: To use credentials, click the Credentials tab and configure the following properties:

row.entry: Authentication to use. To use authentication, select Username/Password.
